This anime really emotional. This anime struck through my heart. Its not like those random animes that involve magic or love. The events in this anime took place in an earthquake of magnitude 8.0. This is an anime that is based off a true story.( or at least i think. )It teaches you about how much you should never take granted of life. The girl in the story shows you about how much she dislike her life, and the world, especially her little brother and her parents, until one day a huge earthquake struck the place where she lives. She realized about how much sheloves her whole entire family, and the anime shows how slowly the siblings connect to each other.\n\n
This is probably what most peoples had faced on March 11, 2011, the day when Tokyo, Japan had fell. So, think of this anime as if its about the peoples who had suffered through the earthquake in japan on that date. Its really touching.

To describe the experience of watching Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 in words would not do this series justice.  Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 is to this date, the best anime I've watched hands down.  Personally extremely strict with my ratings and to rate an anime series 8 and above is rare.  Tokyo Magnitude does not betray any great expectations that I had when starting this series.
It leaves raw emotions bringing the audience to experience the feelings of the character, treating the audience to a roller coaster ride of emotions.  It is an indescribable feeling and to try to put the experience of watching TokyoMagnitude would understate it.  \n\n
A truly inexpressible experience.  A series you cannot miss.  And I really mean it.

/!\ SPOILERS /!\
Tokyo Magnitude starts very well, but ends bad enough. It is assumed that this anime is a recreation studied after "extensive research" (put it at the beginning of each chapter). So far so good, the first 4-5 chapters shows you the consequences of an earthquake and situations that could happen and it's like it warns you of what can happen to you and tells you what to do if you happen to be in such a situation, but starting of half-series all this begins to become a personal drama and deepens in the life of the protagonists. For example, when they go hometo one who knows Mari and tell a little about his life (when Mari meets her husband and the story of Yuuki and the robot geek). Or the very stupid "drama" of when they find the bodies of an old woman and a girl in a shelter and it is already assumed that it is Mari's family, without removing the blanket from her face in order to identify them, so that three minutes later, Mirai and Yuuki find the true relatives who were alive. That is, you get a absurd drama that three minutes is solved. Hello? And also when Yuuki dies and Mirai sees his ghost (or whatever). I thought at first that it was a product of his imagination because he ended up in shock but he is put back into another drama that could have been saved because it is a RECREATION, not a drama of "h my otouto dies". It seems that in the end Yuuki is a ghost and not a product of Mirai's imagination, since when she leaves not to return, she is fading and saying things that Mirai does not understand. I mean, ghosts in an anime about earthquakes? Then they put some scenes of moments of the life of Yuuki trying to make you cry, making a cheap drama, more than anything because at no time it is said why it dies. Does he die from sunstroke (this was mentioned but not confirmed) and the child does not complain? Any child would complain and if it is so heated he could have said to stand in a shade and drink water (which they do). Come on, that his death does not make sense, they get to dramatize and sympathize with the viewer.\n\n
In summary, that of an anime that in theory is a studied recreation of the consequences of an earthquake (I repeat that they put a text at the beginning of each episode remembering it), starts very well but half goes completely by the branches and becomes An absurd drama. And that not to mention the lousy animation, that had been "pardoned" for being an anime that had instructive principles.

It's all going down. The whole of Tokyo is crumbling due to an 8.0 magnitude earthquake, and with it is crumbling the life of a 7th-grade teenage girl Mirai. Stranded away from her home and parents with her younger brother and another woman named Mari, will she be able to complete her journey home?
I cannot really categorize Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 in a good or bad category. Part of it makes you think that you should probably watch something else while part of it doesn't let you stop seeing it even for a second.
The overall premise of the story is good and it is what compelledme to start watching it. After the 1st three quarters, I felt that it was a really good story gone waste but the last quarter does the work of binding together everything and providing a sense of completeness at the end. This anime is much more than just about an earthquake and how lives are destroyed by it. It is about a girl, rowdy and pessimistic at the beginning and her journey as she comes round to realize what truly matters and how certain events change the way she thinks about things and people.


The artwork is breathtaking. There are some amazing shots of building and the surroundings which are a treat to watch. Especially the shots of bridge and Tokyo tower in the initial episodes and the details in which they are shown is amazing. The character sketches are not that great and mainly kept simple, but that also draws your attention to the minute details in the background. 



The background is probably the biggest let down of the anime. The score at the time of earthquake isn't really that great and it also doesn't complement emotions in those tender scenes. But again, the last 3 episodes are the highlight of the anime and the background score fits perfectly here. The op is not that great the ed is pretty good and works well after you have completed the show.


The characters lack depth, except perhaps Mirai. There's not much work done in this front. But then it can also be because it was to be primarily her show. Yuki as the younger brother is perhaps the most likable character you will come across in this anime. 


I didn't really enjoy much, except the last 3 episodes. It was something which I was not really hooked to. Yes, the episodes ended well and prepared the base for the next one, but there was nothing much going on in terms of character development in the initial stages.


Overall, Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 is a good anime, if not an average one. It can get kind of depressing at times, and will surely make you cry a lot towards the end as the journey comes to an end. But it also has those sunny, happy moments provided by Yuki which provide a respite from the otherwise gloomy surroundings. 


It's not a tale of survival, it's a tale of a journey back home.

This is one of the most saddest ones I've seen. I think almost every episode or so, I cried. Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 uses real life disasters, as if they were to happen in real life. That point really got to me. I fully recommend this anime, as it brings realization as to what really happens in those type of situations. People die, buildings fall, and things just fall down on your world. I really enjoyed this one.

THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS
It was hard to write this review about this drama. An anime about the realistic depiction of an earthquake may be the reason why it got such high praise, the character interactions had flaws and the story was just OK. So, I wasn't extremely sad when Yuuki died. Mari is about the only character who stuck with me and got me through this long torturous journey. 
Mirai is a despicable teenager who acts like a child, hence may be the reason why she is treated like one. Also, she has this relationship with Mari that I felt was excessively motherly. Her brothercould also be a little too childish, but he's just a young kid so I don't have that much of a problem with it.


The twist with Yuuki was quite predictable, I did think something was wrong with him keep disappearing and reappearing and how was he able to survive that surgery, by the way?


I think that the anime should've been shortened to about 9-10 episodes long, it was a bit boring but it may have been because I was sleepy at the time. There's not really anything inappropriate in it aside from one bad word but it's too scary and Yuuki's death would be too distressing for young teens to handle.


You may try it but don't expect anything too special. It's mainly something you can watch to pass the time. But you may just forget about what happened in the next couple of days.

i have seen a large portion of anime/TV/manga ext, but out of all of them I'd say there are only 3 of them that were so well done, tragic, and just plain outstanding that it actually made em cry, the first was chrono crusade, the second was clannad, and then of course we have tokyo magnitude 8.0, as of right now i had just finished the serise about 30 min. ago and it was one of a kind but ill break it down into parts now.
story (9/10) the plot is just as you read in the synopsis, its a earthquake hitting tokyo city and effectit has, there isn't much depth to it but this is a character piece and it focuses all on our 3 mains and the side characters that they come across and not the earthquake itself, it feels like the earthquake is just a secondary thing when all the real drama and enjoyment comes form the characters, 


art(8/10) this is a studio BONES so its always guaranteed to look outstanding with there distinctive color pallet and fluid movements, and while this shows first 6 episodes look outstanding after that you can tell the later episodes have a much lower budget seeing how theres not much destruction in the later episodes, which is ok but the art takes a noticeable dip in quality but sitll good


sound(10/10) acting is phenomenal on everyones part. Satomi Hanamura portrays mirai's personality perfectly and realy sells it in the last ep, same going with Yumiko Kobayashi as yuki who actually sounds like a kid, everyone is really good at acting in the show and Yūko Kaida really sounds like a mom in her 20 to 30's, the music is outstanding, its rare to find a show where the music is extremely memorable but tokyo magnitude pulls it off, some track fit scenes perfectly and while its no clannad ost its still very well done


characters(10/10) wether its our 3 mains yuki, mirai, and mari or one of the 1 shot characters that only appear for a episode everyone is extremely likable. some of the one shot characters may come off insane but still likable like the robotku who is obsessed with robots, the main 3 are easily the most likable and are all realistic and develop, our MC mirai acts her age, shes a 11 year old so naturally shes bratty and full of herself like we all were back then, yuki is a little less realistic but is believable enough to the point where you could imagine a kid with his personality existing in real life, and finally mari who acts like a real mother, she hides her fear and worries so she doesn't frighten the children(mirai and yuki) but as a human she has her breaking points and as the serise progresses she grows more and more worried about things and a certain plot point i wont spoiled introduced very early, the characters are great and develop well,


enjoyment(10/10) if the premise doesn't give it away this show is downright depressing,  its not for those easily upset especially with the horrible events that happened in real life recently, now actual enjoyment it will keep you interested even in the calmer episodes halfway through, its very enjoyable and will leave you in denial till it happens for the last 4 episodes,


overall(10/10) yah the near non existent story and animation dip halfway through doesn't stop this form being what it is, and thats a realistic prediction of what would happen to tokyo in a few years, the show is depressing and while there is one significantly obvious twist it will still leave you shocked from it and may leave you in tears like it did me, this is one of a kinda and well worth watching. and make sure to sit through the credits, how they do the epilogue is very well done even though i didn't get to see much of it since my vision was blurred from crying so much in the previous 5 min prior

So what was probably the biggest series no one really talked aboot of last season, Tokyo Magnitude was rather intense for its short length...What I would describe as a "disaster movie done right," TM delivered on all the emotion and impact a disater movie SHOULD...
The series is slow but done well enough that you;'re never bored...Locales are meticulously detailed and then destroyed shortly after they're introduced...It's almost wherever the main characters go, destruction follows!!
The bulk of the series is getting from point a to point b and staying safe the entire time...
Around episode 9/10 (IIRC) the twist hits and it is INSANELY sad...It didn't hitme as hard as say Grave of the Fireflies did, but damn, it sucks...No spoiler here folks, no worries...\n\n
While I can't say much and not spoiling anything, TM was enjoyable from start to finish and while the main character got on my nerves every now and again, she IS 11 or 12, so she plays her young/immature self really well...

Boy, did Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 (TM8) come out of nowhere and completely surprise me.
Story: 10/10
The story is fascinating and fresh. There is a disclaimer at the beginning of each episode that states a large amount of research concerning earthquakes and such were done as the show is striving for realism. The show is fiction, but this sense of realism adds to the emotional story. Further, the flow of the story, for the most part, is excellent and will make viewers want to watch the episodes consecutively.
Animation: 8/10
The character drawings range from “average” at worst to “very good” at best. In some scenes, the characters looklazily drawn, but it gets the point across and is not annoying to look at. The backdrop has much more detail and is often times excellent in quality. The CG scenes are well done too. The difference in quality between the character and setting animations is to increase the overall realism and devastation caused by the earthquake.


Characters: 10/10


The characters are exceptional. Everyone is believable and very likeable. The protagonists grow with the unfolding events and are a main reason why the story is so moving. Further, the supporting cast is also well done. One can connect with any of the side characters and sympathize with their situation. In addition, the voice actors did an excellent job of conveying the tone and emotion to put an genuine spin on their characters (especially Mari and Yuuki’s seiyuus).


Music: 8/10


Kimi No Uta’s (opening) music and lyrics are fitting for the chaotic events and describe the protagonists’ situation well. The ending song, Melody, is very catchy and uplifting. Its “melody” is light and happy which clashes (in a good way) with some of the more serious scenes. The background score, while not exactly memorable by itself, is purposeful and moving.


Enjoyment: 7/10


Why is my gut feeling about this show just slightly above average when all the other qualities are higher? It is because I literally felt like I was punched in my emotional and proverbial gut towards the end of the show. Don’t get me wrong, the ending is far from horrible. It is hard to explain what I’m talking about without spoiling it so let me just simply say that it did its job of evoking my emotions, however I feel that it did too good of a job. We all know too much of a good thing can be bad.  The ending is extremely bittersweet, making me have a love-hate relationship for this series. I am sure other viewers will disagree with my gut feeling. I can see where they are coming from and completely respect that (see my perfect 10/10 score for the story).


Average Series Rating: 8/10 – Very Good


Bottom line: TM8 is a gripping, refreshing, depressing, but extremely entertaining drama. The viewer may want to watch something happier and lighter at the end because it is a real tear jerker. Not exactly my cup of tea (too sad), however I know a special series when I see it.

Tokyo Magnitude 8.0, as the title mentions, this anime series is related to earthquakes on Japan. The story is very good, because it brings up a story that most of the people didn't live, but the japanese people did. There was an earthquakes, a tough one, as the story explains. I did enjoy it a little, before I added it to my "dropped" tab in my list. Why? Well, because of the art. The drawing art is good... but they use too much the process of adding 3 Dimensional elements. When you're in those parts that you can see them as 1 meter away, yousee the characters are typical anime character (with the author's original art) and if they are 2 meters away (or more) you see them as this strange type of 3D elements. This got me pissed off. "Why add those horrible very well noticable elements when the story is amazing? This screws the whole anime!".\n
For me, 3D elements look horrible in animes if they aren't very worked on.\n
However, it's on opinion.

Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 is an unique anime. You rarely see a title showing a catastrophy in here. And not only it is catastrophical, but in fact there is more slice of life theme going on in here. Did this attempt turn out well? Partially.
The story focuses around young middle-school girl called Mirai (which is an interesting name in the contex of the story, since it translates into "future") and her younger brother. Due to her overworking parents, she has the one to take her brother for a visit in some kind of gallery away from her home, where the fatal accident in the title takesplace. Briefly after the earthquake adult woman named Mari decides to help them return to their parents and so the trio starts on their way back, which is pretty much the theme of the entire series.


Now, this anime has only 11 episodes, though looking on what there is in the plot, and there is pretty much nothing but just going back home, it seems that the number is too big. The series has some side stories, but they are rather short and depth-lacking, like the one about guy who liked robots, cause they helped saving people.. Yes, he liked robots and it was just about him liking the robots. The entire episode of just him liking the robots. I'm not even kidding. The more you watch, the more you begin to wonder "what the hell did they fill the next x episodes with?". There is a little turn at the end of episode 8. It would be hard for me to explain the circumstances and what made me not like it without giving out much spoilers, so I will touch as generally as it is possible. The series ends with some kind of inception-like theme going on and the inception itself is a little bit confusing at the end, in a way that you're not completely sure if the plot won't take another twist or there would be a sudden moment of realisation that the girl was just having a bad dream all the time at the very end. This makes is hard for you to go along with the actual action and empathize with the characters. I realize that this story is made to be emotional and tear-jerking, yet I couldn't get the feeling that it was dragged on with a forced ending to it off my head.


For the visuals, there are just mediocre. I don't have much against the background, but I certainly didn't like the way characters were drawn. While Mirai is generally ok, but the boy with her looks plain bad, and the moments when he's supposed to smile resembles me of a parody rather then anything else. The voice isn't that bad, but it doesn't show off too much either. Opening is a bit anti-climatic, it makes you a bit excited and waiting to get in action, while the anime is extremely slow-paced. The ending on the other hand is just brilliant. I loved it and the way it fit with the show unlike the op so much, that I gave +1 score just for the ending theme.


In case of characters it is hard to say much, since there are only 3 of them and each is pretty much one-coloured. There is a handful of side characters, but most of them are as deep as the aforementioned robot guy, so let's just just ignire them for time-being. For the main trio, the one that I certainly didn't enjoy watching is once again the younger brother. He's just over-optimistic, family-loving, everyone-around-concerned-for etc etc child. Everyone he speaks, he merely says anything new or unexpected, and his voice is a bit annoying, when he says everything in a shouting manner. The only character I enjoyed looking at was Mirai, since she was kinda dynamic, turning from depressed, a bit rebellious teen into warm and sympathizing girl. I could sort of identify with her and experience her drama and that was the part of the show I greatly enjoyed.


As far as I'm concerned, this anime could be way more entertaining if they decided to give up on the inception theme. This would also make it shorter, cutting it possibly to 9-10 episodes, but it would also make the ending less confusing, so the viewer could actually enjoy the feeling of katharsis which comes with it. If it would be true, I would be actually willing to give this anime an 8 from the title, however it's not that simple and I'm a bit in two minds when it comes to judging it. On one side I like the overall theme of it and the character development of the main heroine, despite the fact that the anime feels over-extended and even boring, not to mention the confusion around the inception-like end theme. So to say: I liked it and I was bored with it at the same time. If you are looking for a catastrophical anime with high value of realism, as well as some personal drama going on, Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 is a solid recommendation for you. Too bad I can't forget about it flaws, and thus it makes "only" 7.0 earthquake on my scale.

.: REVIEW :.
Title: Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 || Alt. Title: Tokyo Magnitude 8
Genre: Drama, Disaster, Tragedy, Contemporary, Suspense || Writer: Takahashi Natsuko
Director: Masaki Tachibana || Producer: Ozaki Noriko, Matsuka Yuichiro
Original Run: July 9, 2009 – September 17, 2009 || Episode Count: 11 Episodes
Plot –
After a massive earthquake in Tokyo 25 km under the sea at a magnitude of 8.0, siblings Mirai and Yuuki, who were visiting a robot exhibition at Odaiba at the beginning of their summer vacation, struggle to reach their parents in their house in Setagaya, assisted by a female motorcycle courier named Mari, who is striving to reach her own daughter and motherin Sangenjaya. Together, the three brave the ruined city and try their best to make it home safely.\n\n
Characterization and Voice Acting –\n
The series has a young girl named Mirai Onozawa as the leading character whose life and struggles have been pictured in the whole story, to be precise. The other two main characters apart from the lead protagonist are Kusakabe Mari – the lady who helps her and her younger brother – Yuuki Onozawa – to get back to their home safely. The character development in the whole series is praiseworthy. The transitions brought about by the circumstances in the human behavior as a whole has been pictured in a very authentic manner. The voice acting undoubtedly is one of the best. To be more specific, the voice casting of Yuuki is something you should emphasize more on. It is done in a very distinct manner. The innocence and the mental maturity have been reflected very proficiently through the voice casting itself.\n
The side characters – Parents of the Protagonist and others – have been presented in a fair and noteworthy manner as well, although their roles in the series may have been comparatively shorter but still the director managed to give a crystal clear image of the whole case scenario with efficiency.\n
Onozawa, Mirai – Voiced by Hanamura, Satomi (Jap.) and Christian, Luci (Eng.)\n
Onozawa, Yuuki – Voiced by Kobayashi, Yumiko (Jap.) and Grant, Tiffany (Eng.)\n
Kusakabe, Mari – Voiced by Kaida, Yuko (Jap.) and Calene-Black, Shelly (Eng.)\n
Parents of the Protagonist:\n
Onozawa, Senji – Voiced by Naka, Hiroshi (Jap.) and Matranga, David (Eng.)\n
Onozawa, Masami – Voiced by Inoue, Kikuko (Jap.) and Flecknoe, Maggie (Eng.)\n\n
Artwork –\n
The artwork as a whole resembles that of Ghibli’s Spirited Away. It is done in the simplest way possible and hence is able to grab the attention of the watcher. The expressions of the characters under different circumstances are very vividly reflected, apart from the dialogues, mainly through the artwork. Not much detailing, yet very well managed.\n
The importance shall be laid more on the designs and artwork of the buildings and architecture of the towns/cities as a whole. It is very common to present normal townscape scenario anywhere but what is most challenging is to make it look as real as possible after the disaster effect. The damage and the property loss as a whole have been presented in a very efficient manner, too undoubtedly.\n\n
Ratings –\n
Plot: Gets a rating of 7.5/10 from me as it is nothing extraordinary in nature. It is a work of fiction based on a random character’s life during the time of a disaster which really took place in Tokyo in recent times. Still, it deserves a rating of 7.5+.\n
Character Design and Voice Acting: On this ground in particular, I rate the series as 8/10 – wrt to the Character Design, Animation and Voice Casting\n
Artwork: For artwork, the series gets an 8.5/10\n
Average Rating: 8/10\n
MyAnimeList Rating: 8.2/10 || IMDB Rating: 8.1/10

Anime Review: Tokyo Magnitude 8.0
Story: The story, in itself is simple. It is the events of the tokyo earthquake from the perspective of 3 characters, their struggle, and what they do to survive. It is the story telling that is this anime's selling point. That is done exceptionally well.
Score: 3/4 due to lack of actual story depth.
Characters: Average characters. your average brother sister combo, with a caring passerby. the type of characters that befit the story, but nothing necessary to advance the story, or add any value.
Score: 0.5/1
Sound/Music: Proper ambient sounds and noises to add tot he environment, soft voice acting that fits the characters.no outstanding music to amplify any emotions during the anime though.\n
Score: 0.5/1\n\n
Animation: nice to look at characters. good scenery. voices fit the character designs, and vice versa. adds to the atmosphere the story creates. soft and warm.\n
Score: 1/1\n\n
Enjoyment: Minor distractions here and there that loses focus. but all adds value to the story in general. like i said earlier, the story telling is very enjoyable, being able to see the struggles from the perspective of ordinary people during the crisis.\n
Score: 3/4\n\n
Total: 8/10 [not every anime needs good character, or good animation. thus among character, music, animation, one is a bonus. this way an anime can be 10/10 even if it scores 0 in the animation department]\n\n
Recommendation: watch it. it is a master of its kind, which is telling a tragic story. none of the emotions we feel are forced, and comes naturally.

Tokyo Magnitude 8.0
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Story:
The story centers on Mirai, A young girl who has to take her Younger brother Yuuki out to a Robot Convention, Mirai is one of those Teens who seem to dislike her parents and take for granted other family members. She basically wishes for something to happen and that something happens, An Earthquake that measured 8.0, From this they are helped by Mari who's mission is to get them both back to their parents, The series follows the adventure traveling back to their home to find out if their parents are alive or not.
Characters:
What makes this series a really good one, is thecharacter development, You see through this tragic event of the earthquake, Mirai, Matures and becomes more thankful to people who help her and also due to this we can see her brother Yuuki real side to her, and loving side that she didn't see before.


Tragedy can bring people together and that is what is portrayed wonderfully in this series.


Overview:


For me this series is a 8/9 out of 10, Its something Unique, Story has its fair share of Drama and Lighthearted moments, You really become attached to these characters by the way the Story hardly shifts it's focus from the 3 characters and it does feel like an Epic Journey. 

Being 11 Episodes is the perfect length for this series, It didn't overstay its welcome but put enough content for a good & satisfying ending.


This series does really show the plight from a massive disaster, How many innocent lives are lost and the massive destruction of your home/town or city, But when hard times hits everyone, people are resilient and find strength to carry on and help others.


So go and watch this series, Its a superb series and worth your time watching, even though its quite short at 11 Episodes.

Story:\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
9/10
The story initially seemeda little slow paced, but merited a second watch after seeing the ending.\n
The slow pace that the story takes doesn't detract from the enjoyment. After all, the show is only 11 episodes long.\n
Oh my goodness though, it is so very worth it. I couldn't say much more about the plot's virtues without straying into spoilers. Just watch it.\n\n

8/10\n

8/10\n

Story: I've never experienced an earthquake before. I know very little about them... But this anime has this type of ... miserable, impending doom kind of feel to it. And that's what I think you'd want if you're even considering watching this in the first place. The story focuses on three earthquake survivors on their journey to their homes, and it deals with the repercussions of the disaster.
Art: Art is pretty gently, honestly. It's nothing too amazing, but definitely nothing bad about it either.
Sound: Never really know what to say about the sound when I'm writing reviews. The explosive noises of earthquakes really added tothe horrific nature you'd expect in this type of series, I suppose?\n\n
Characters: It's very easy to start caring about the characters, since it pretty much focuses solely on Mirai, Yuuki, and Mari... \n\n
I enjoyed it. It felt pretty realistic, though once again I've never experienced an earthquake myself. Watch it and judge for yourselves, I suppose.

Ever wanted to kill hundreds of people with just one email? Well, that isn't what the show is about, but this show does feature the deaths of many as Japan suffers a severe earthquake. This show was a joy ride from the beginning all the way to the end, and though it may be a slow ride it was a joyous one to watch. The show as stated before is about a severe earthquake that hits Japan, and follows a teenage girl and her little brother through the tough aftermath as they travel back home. As aftershocks hit, they run into a friendly woman whohas agreed to see them home and travel as a group of three to help one another out through physical and mental struggles. Each episode shows a new moment in the in catastrophe, and the adventure that one shouldn't have to experience.


Sidenote: A good show to watch if you have no idea what to watch, I will say though the show is kinda slow paced. I don't mind slow paced shows if the story is good, which this show did have an interesting story.


Story: The story was pretty nice, an interesting turn from other shows out there. It was slow paced, but at the same time it seemed just interesting enough to keep my attention and seemed to fly by. The idea of it all was really good, it takes place in a demolished Japan after a serious earthquake, and shows the after math and struggles one and many would have if it were to occur today.


Characters: The characters were alright, they weren't the most creative, but they were fun. The only reason why they aren't labeled generic would be the situations they were placed in and how realistically they deal with them. The characters do also develop in the show which is spectacular, the way they acted towards one other from beginning to end was real and human like. Although as I do praise the characters, I would like to point out minor flaws. The characters might do or say some generic things, as in they act in a way that seems too anime to be real (if that makes sense). That would be my only problem with them, and it doesn't happen that often, but when it does it's a minor issue.


Art & Sound: This show did have some really great scenes with some nice design and nice detail to destroyed landscapes. Sets in the show were real for the situation, and the design for them were nicely drawn and colored. Nothing looked too dull nor too flashy, which is fantastic. My only issues though would be the use of cheap 3D models for characters in the background. Although I list that as an issue, it wasn't too noticeable and for the most part it wasn't overused and obvious. I also had some issues with the subtitles, for some of the important text would be colored differently from the not so important text. What I mean by that is usually if other characters are talking their dialogue would be colored, usually yellow. This show had yellow text but would make main dialogue yellow and the other text white, and it's easy to adjust to but it was weird seeing it for the first time. 


Overall the show was good, but with a few cliche scenes. Although everything was great and unique, the show did use some elements that seemed maybe a little out of place. Also some things were predictable, and it is practically unavoidable for the lead up to some of the reveals made them obvious before they could reveal them.


Good show to watch, if your interested definitely put it in your plan to watch.

I have watched a lot of anime and its nice to watch one that is so realistic.The characters have lots of development over only 11 episodes and most importantly it has a perfect ending and doesnt try to make the whole thing into just a nightmare.
The situation in the last few episodes was dealt with so realistically and made me cry more than anything i have seen so far.I think that it deserves a 10 because of that alone.

Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 is about tragedy, a simulation of an earthquake occurring in tokyo as the name already says for itself, but in addition to focusing on the earthquake, the anime is about the problems faced by those who survive the event, what are and how to face their problems.
One of the problems presented by anime is about family power, as you might imagine, in such a situation is not unlikely that some parents find themselves separated and can not make contact with their families.
This is the situation of the 3 main characters of the story, two of whom are brothers (Mirai and Yuuki) andother (Mari) is helping them to go home.


The idea then is to show what happens when you are in a situation where you can't rely on people you know (friends and family). Do you value the company of your parents, siblings and friends? only when you are depending on yourself is that the answer to this question appears.


In this climate the anime proves to be very good, many people show their egocentric way, angry with the situation as it was expected, on the other hand there are also people who tend to help those who are most disadvantaged.


Finally, I really liked the way the anime shows the feel of the characters, you not only sympathizes, but feel empathy for them, my final thought was that any tragedy we face in life, we can divide us and face it alone or unite ourselfs as humans and overcome the problems toghether, it's all a matter of choice.

Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 is a moving tale about two siblings caught in a inevitable situation of a 8.0 earthquake and is based on a hypothetical situation of a earthquake occurring along with being produced after research and inspection of facts. The story overall is very moving and it conveys very well the effects and devastation an earthquake of that or any magnitude could cause on not just the environment but the effects on the people's mentality and health. It is a very moving tale about two siblings called Mirai Onozawa and Yukki Onozawa who, along with meeting a woman along the way called Mari Kusakabi,focus on getting home to their families whilst on their journey coming across the struggles that the earthquake has brought upon them and those around them. 


I found the story very moving and at times uplifting, Mirai Onozawa seems rather negative and pessimistic whilst her brother Yukki is very uplifting, energetic and positive. The woman Mari Kusakabi is rather the 'mother' of the group who offers guidance and makes sure that all of them make it home safely. It is good that you can see along the journey how much they grow, particularly Mirai, and how each take from each other their strong points to make it through. The story seems to flow rather well, I think sometimes there were a couple of knocks where I felt they were trying to stretch it a bit and it seemed to drag a tad but overall I think the last few episodes make up for that. 


I think the animation was very good, particularly the environment as it did good portrayal of the devastation and ruins, the rubble and broken houses, the uneven slabs of pavement, I think it captured the whole feel of the earthquake. I think the animations of the characters were good, I would say they weren't very bright but it could be to make the environment stand out. I did feel that the characters expressions looked rather gone out and paper thin at times but it didn't really distract from the whole experience. 


I would say the music was so-so, I wouldn't say it was bad but not very memorable but it did well to convey the emotions in certain scenes. I must say  that the ED/Ending song was quite memorable to me, it did leave a good impression on me, quite moving and enthusiastic, it certainly got me pumped for the next episode. The voice acting was quite good, I think they matched their characters very well, particularly Yukki as it certainly matched his sparky positive personality, I could have no qualms about it. 


Overall I enjoyed this anime, it made me smile at times and it made me tear up too, it certainly did well at pulling at my heartstrings and it gave that whole impression and feeling of loving what you have, not taking things for granted.

Non spoiler review
This movie has been an emotional ride for me and I greatly enjoyed it. The art and sound are good but where it really shines is in the story telling and character development. 
The characters look believable when faced with the different situations. Plot is good and tragic, also who would believe that roughly 3 years later after the movie was screened, tragedy would strike Japan for real. 
The portrayal of the earthquake, its aftermath and the subsequent aftershocks is very well done. You kind of feel the terror of the aftershocks, never knowing when they will strike, if the building you arein will collapse.  Earthquakes really shake your life, one of the most despicable forces of nature and in this movie it really shakes the lives of the main characters to the core. \n\n
This is a movie that will make you tear up and change your views about family and brothers/sisters. There is a lot of realism presented from the search and recovery units of the JDF to the places portrayed in Tokyo. \n
My biggest complaint about this movie is the length of time it takes the main characters to journey from Odaiba to Setagaya (approx. 15km walk on google maps – let’s say 20km with detours). This distance can be covered in a day once you’ve crossed Tokyo Bay. The other complaint is Mari as a character, although nicely developed, she seems forced, I don’t think there are people that would actually take on helping 2 kids when faced in a crisis situation of their own.  If there really are such people, it’s great, the world needs more like that. If put in such a situation, I don’t know what I would do actually. This movie is good at making you question yourself and also in showing how fragile our society is (lack of phone coverage for example in a crisis, how you lose contact with your loved ones, lack of food, shelter, medicines, etc).\n\n
Final thoughts, movie is great and underrated in my opinion. Have your paper towels handy for the last episodes, you might need them, ending is quite powerful. Let’s hope that tragedies like in this anime stay in the anime and do not happen in Japan or anywhere else in the world. Japan, more than any other country in the world, knows how to pick-up after a natural tragedy (they had so many so far), life is never the same after that however, the Japanese are good in understanding and showing this through this anime. \n

Mirai is practically useless, the only other character that causes more trouble than her is her little brother Yuuki who is always running off for no reason and saying the dumbest stuff and character wise is as deep as one of those toys who can say 3 meaningless, cliche sentences.\n
The theme is repetitive and I soon cought myself thinking- when will this be over or when will something meaningful happen?\n
I had such high hopes for this anime, because the premise is interesting and in my head i could already picture many ways it could unfold a unique kind of story from an interesting point, but it didnt. Its just trying to get 'the feels' by using little kids, few cenes of dead relatives and fear of losing those close to you, which can be a tear jerker and can provoke people to think unless you make characters two dimensional and they remain just like storm troopers in Star Wars- faceless and put there just to die in the background. \n
I do have to admit first two eisodes did get me hyped up, but thats probably because ive never seen an earthquake. \n\n

First off, this is heartbreaking. I finished this anime about 2 minutes ago and let me just say, my house ran out of tissues. I loved this anime because not only did it make me laugh and cry, it also allowed me to see how much of an effect an earthquake like this could impact the environment and people!
   The plot for Tokyo Magnitude was fantastic. It could be very relate able at times especially when the two siblings got mad at each other. Usually, it would be Mirai scolding her younger brother and him being hurt, but he didn't say anything aboutthat much. They meet Mari and hit it off and they seemed like a family. The story definitely kept you in suspense.


    The art was very realistic when it came to the destruction that the earthquake brought. The characters were nicely drawn and fit somewhere in the middle of cartoon-y and anime-y, but in my opinion, that's the best place.


     Even if you closed your eyes and kept on listening, I think you could definitely tell that an earthquake was occurring. All the other sounds were great too, when the characters were talking, when machines or robots were moving, anything to be honest.  


      Okay. The characters. Don't even get me started! They seemed so real and it felt as if I was best friends with them and knew every little detail about them. It was obvious that the creators thought about their personality really hard, and it showed. 


     The only, and I mean ONLY reason I gave enjoyment a 9 was because it made me so sad. This is definitely not a bad thing. I love sad anime (I don't know, I'm just weird like that okay?) and honestly, I feel like this is a great anime that plays with your feelings. Of course I enjoyed this anime, I mean, who couldn't?


     Overall, I loved this anime. Of course, it made me sob as well as die inside a little, but I love it none the less. You should definitely give it a try and plus, if you don't like it, it's not very long anyways (which is a bummer).

Anime Review
Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 (11 Episodes)
Rating: 6/10 (Fine)
Recommendation Level: Stream It
Yes, a lot of reviews are hitting my Facebook today. That's what happens when you finally had some free time to catch up on your collection. There will be a few more before the day's end, so I apologize ahead of time if this is a nuisance.
Story:
Mirai and Yuuki are siblings. Mari is at the age where she, well do you remember middle school? Yeah it's that. And Yuuki is a in elementary school. Wth their parents always working, Mari is asked to take Yuuki to robot exhibit on the other side of town. Whilethey're there, an earthquake hits Tokyo. The two meet up with Mari, lady in her mid to late 20's. And the three of them try to find their way back home amidst the devastating earthquake.


When you think of natural disaster movies, shows, et cetera. What do you generally think of? I bet you're thinking about constant destruction. Well, you're going to be surprised about this one.


The plot of Tokyo Magnitude is very slow. The main idea of the anime is to grow the characters, in a span of about a week. Maybe less. There isn't constant destruction or huge obstacles that get in the way at every turn. It's more of a peaceful setting. The "good" side of a disaster. The kindness and thoughtfulness of others is what shines through most in this show. Which is a slight downfall.


During a time in need, we want to have people to help us. We want to come together as a community and grow stronger from these events. The only problem is that Tokyo Magnitude doesn't really hit home with the viewer. The light hearted tone doesn't give this natural disaster a lot of weight, so in return, we can't feel the full affects of just occurred. Until the end. That was something I didn't really see coming.


Characters:


Mirai: Moody, doesn't like to be bothered with much, finds everything annoying or uncool.


Yuuki: Optimistic, friendly, cheerful, never complains, wants what's best for others.


Mari: Older, wiser, very calm, handles situations really well, doesn't jump to conclusions, a lot of compassion and determination.


As you can tell, Tokyo Magnitude is about the characters and their journey. The overall plot takes a back seat as you watch Mirai grow up, in a matter of days, and see how the characters appreciate life with every step they take forward towards home. It's one of the better character anime I've ever seen.


Animation & Sound:


The animation is serviceable. With the exception of a few destruction scenes, there isn't a lot to exactly showcase. On another note, the destroyed buildings don't give off a lot of despair because of the light hearted tone. Which is fine if you're looking for something with more happiness than sadness.


The music, meh. Nothing really note worthy here. The opening is okay but it's instantly forgettable.


The dub is where it's at. Other than Greg Ayres and Brittney Karbowski voicing every single side character, the main cast is excellent. They picked up the best for this anime.


Overall: 


If you were expecting a grand anime, with a lot of destruction and survival elements thrown in, you're going to be severely disappointed. This anime tears me up because on one hand, the characters are tremendous. On the other, the story is really, really slow. Almost too the point where it's hard to finish because nothing really happens, up until the last three episodes.


This anime is more on the good side than bad. But I honestly believe that's because of the last two episodes that leave a, possible cheap ending. One that you don't see coming, unless you're really paying attention, or guessed it from a certain point on. It'll either strike the right chord with you, or piss you off.


Final advice, if you do choose to view it, take your time with it. It's not something that's popcorn made. It's meant to be slow and developing. Whether you like it or not, that'll be totally up to your taste.

7.5/10

Okay, so there really is not much to say about this anime from my point of view. I'm not much for writing reviews but I for whatever reason felt a need to do so this time.
As stated above, not really much to say. It's a disaster movie. An earthquake takes place and people are displaced, many die, get wounded, ect ect. This young girl and her brother are at a robot exhibit when the earthquake takes place. They meet a woman who decides to help them get home since they live in the same direction. Really, because of how simple it is, it's just likeany disaster movie out there. The thing is, the characters fit perfectly, voice acting was great. The art work was low quality compared to some of the better anime out there, but it's not terrible.


To do a full review though, I personally consider a disaster movie/anime to be typical... so I generally would not think they would be rated all that high. This i'd put at 8 for story simply because it's typical. The delivery of this story though was very well laid out. This is why it's rated as high as it was.


Art: 6


As mentioned it's not great but it works.


Sound: 7


Sound was not crisp, but i enjoyed the op/ed themes, and the sound during the anime itself fit the scenario very well.


Characters: 9


I really enjoyed the way the characters played out. The development, the side characters. They fit the scenario, completed the story, and the young girl for example developed her personality and attitude about things throughout the anime.


Enjoyment: 9


The enjoyment level really caught me off guard on this. When I started watching it, I had low expectations. I believed it would just be an average anime. The story line played out well and I grew to really like how things took place. Going back to the story, it was very realistic on how things could happen, and even gave you some shocks and emotional play during this anime.


Overall: 8.0


Ironically overall i'd rate this as 8.0. It's not TOP of the line, but it was very enjoyable which is obviously the most important part. I hope everyone else enjoys it as much as I did.

I just finished watching this series and it was extremely good for only being 11 episodes. Its about an earthquake that hits Japan and the story follows a brother and sister who are trying to make it back home to there mom and dad. It shows the good and bad of human kind as they struggle for survival in the wake of a disaster but its definitely not your typical end of the world disaster type series that's for sure.

I'm not much of a reviewer. I just feel a need to recommend this further by describing it in relation to the categories given.
The story. It is simple, as in the synopsis. There is no over complication or simplification. It is realistic, and clearly aims to be. It is absolutely character driven. Even if they're annoying at first you will want to see the Mirai, Yuuki and Mari get to their homes safely.
Art - in the first episode or two, I didn't like it, but somehow it grew on me, much like every aspect of this anime. The art doesn't distract negatively or positively fromthe plot and the characters.


Sound - in terms of soundtrack and the general fx relating to the whole earthquake situation we have going on here, again the soundtrack feels right. Your not distracted by it, and emotional moments are enhanced. I'm a working musician, so I do easily get turned off by some anime's if the music is hopelessly unrelated, or too loud so that I listen to the music instead! I didn't like the opening theme, but I find it hard to consider that as related, and I don't think I listened to the ending theme ever, because I had to continue to the next episode as quickly as possible! The voice acting is great. The characters are really brought to life , specifically their vulnerability and their humanity.


Character - this is where its at. The characters themselves are interesting and develop well. You get to see perspectives change in desperate situations and its all done very well. I know this is going to be one of the few series I will remember forever. Apart from the character ... its character!


Obviously I enjoyed it. You'd be making a grave error to pass this one over, though I'm sure I had done in the past!

First of all: only giving 8s to Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 is not a prank or joke.
Tokyo M8 has a number of strong points, and a number of weaker ones, so this review will actually be component-developed (e.g. "let's discuss the art!") rather than pro-con comparing, in order to keep complexity to a minimum and meaningfulness to a maximum.
So, let's discuss the art! It is widely resonating with the anime: while showing the harshness of the context, it does let a few rays of hope through. You can see actual people with dreams, fears and hopes walk on the gritty textures of concrete blocks and theasphalt. However, this sometimes works against certain climaxes (which I won't mention as not to spoiler anything). The colour palette however does let me a bit down: considering the drawing style, I'd have adapted a more vivid could range, maybe thus further emphasizing the greys. All in all, the art isn't bad at all, but I'd work on the colours. Nothing that a good post-processing can't fix.


The sound is widely enjoyable: the voice actors do get in the part, and perform extremely well. Ambiental sounds are very accurate too, which isn't banale when working with huge events or big machines.


On to the supposedly strong point of Tokyo M8: Characterization. It should be noted that the authors took a clear stance on this, as they follow the story from the eyes of a 12 years old girl, certainly one of the most psychologically turbulent ages of one's life (usually).

Taken the authors wish in consideration, one surely appreciates the emotional journey of young Mirai and her sidekicks, her little brother Yuuki and delivery-woman Mari. The dialogues are meaningful, well tought of, and carefully phrased. Not once a character is estranged from his role. However, this inherently implies a rather linear developing of the plot, if one can read through the characters.

A funny note: maybe the authors didn't realize, but they quoted a play from ancient rome, the Heautontimorùmenos (big bad ass greek compound for "The self-punishing"), where a character says "Homo sum, humani nihil a me alienum puto", through the answer Mari gives to the question "Why are you helping us?".


Overall, Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 is widely enjoyable, and may teach us something we didn't know about Japanese disaster handling (which I regard as state of the art in its sector). Look at it, it won't be time wasted!

Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 is enjoyable if you're looking for a very broad representation of what surviving an earthquake is like. It touched on a few aspects like the sometimes-necessity of grouping with strangers, dealing with being a survivor in a situation where others did not survive, and the nagging fear/question of if those you have been separated from have perished. 
My biggest issues were the obvious attempt to dodge a mature audiences rating. To be in the action of an earthquake, deal with death, fear, and pain - you can't hold back on the storytelling aspects. The scenes that were supposed to contain the mostintensity made you cover your eyes and turn away at the last second, just before you started to feel what you needed to. I didn't need to see gore, but there was no sight of blood or realistic wounds on the survivors. You need to feel the intensity to understand the pain, and this story pulled all of it's readied punches. So be prepared to try and experience suffering while in a room of pillows.\n\n
This story had great potential that was scarified for the sake of keeping a low audience rating. If you want to show your kid what an earthquake might be like without absolutely terrifying them, this is a great anime. But for us that wanted the truest experience possible, this anime just isn't it.

I've just completed the series in about 2 days and in all honesty I'm shocked it has received the ratings it has. Anyways, I'll be straight to the point, the anime was just lackluster. On paper, the events that occur during and after a massive 8.0 earthquake in the huge city of Tokyo should be entertaining, correct? Wrong. After the massive earthquake and a number of "aftershocks" which I expected to be entertaining, I instead found myself easily  bored and straying away from the anime. I found myself in a continuous cycle of "dramatic" events that were predictable and a main character who asrealistic as she is, was just hard to watch. The only saving grace would be the girl's little brother, whose innocence made up for the girl's insolence. Anyways, I somehow made it past 5 episodes and at this point I seriously considered dropping this anime. I was almost halfway done, and even at this point I still felt nothing for the characters and there wasn't a single thread of emotion that kept me to continue the show. I mean, this is supposed to be in the drama genre isn't it? Anyways, I came back on MAL, read a couple of more reviews and decided it would be worth my time to skim past a few more episodes and see if it would regain my attention. By now, the story FINALLY begins to pick up and a series of events begin to occur that I finally start to register. The story continues to pick up and starts to get somewhat interesting and by the end I suppose I can feel somewhat satisfied with the end result. I'm not a huge anime person and I kind of skipped an important scene so I was quite surprised with the ending. I didn't see it coming and after reflecting back, it was quite alluded to. Maybe it was my incoherence during the latter episodes that led to me so surprised, but albeit, I'll give an obligatory 7/10 just for the ending. I'm still overall disappointed with the show, as I was expecting more but I suppose it is the end result that really matters. For me, it was one of those animes which you end up finishing for the sake of it and end up forgetting in a few weeks/months time.
